Scholarship Awarded

Elias Jones was a member of the class of 2013 at Prince Edward County High School when he died suddenly. Since then, his family and friends have honored his memory by awarding a scholarship to a member of the graduating class of PECHS. This scholarship recognizes a student for leadership skills and strength of character. This year the scholarship is awarded to Alia Muhammad.

Alia is a student athlete who served as captain of the volleyball team. She also has been active in student body government and as an officer in the National Honor Society. She is active in the community and has volunteered at FACES food pantry. She is described as friendly, thoughtful, energetic, hard-working and kind.
It is with great pleasure that the family recognizes Alia and we wish her well in her future endeavors.

Wednesday Stories {A Moment in Prince Edward History}
Meet Barbara Spring | Text by Hannah Rawls | Longwood Student

Little 7-year old Barbara was about to enter first grade when the schools closed in 1959 in Prince Edward County, Virginia.

Spring (as one of a set of triplets) and her ten siblings were all shut out.

In 1963, she attended the Free Schools with her two brothers. Graduating from Prince Edward County Public Schools in 1971, she attended
Longwood University, then wanted to get into law enforcement.

In 1974, she was hired in Richmond as a police officer, later becoming the first black female firefighter in the city of Richmond, VA. Barbara served many years before retiring in 2004.

Say, hi! to Barbara if you see her around town. She attends New Life Church.

Over the course of these three days, every 8th grader was given the opportunity to visit every classroom in the CTE Building. Each CTE Teacher was spent about 10 minutes introducing the basics within their particular trade area and showed the 8th graders projects they could expect to work on. Dr. Green, Assistant Principal at the Middle School, and the 8th grade teachers also toured the building. They mentioned their appreciation of the 10 PECHS Seniors that were the tour guides for the 8th graders. These Seniors were knowledgeable of the CTE trades and helped to answer questions and show the ins and outs of the CTE Building. post_text: On February 24, 26, and 27, the Teachers at the Career and Technical Education Center hosted 8th Grade Visitation Days. Each CTE Teacher spent about 10 minutes introducing the basics within their particular trade area and showed the 8th graders projects they could expect to work on. The hope is that after the visit, the 8th grades would have a better idea of their scheduling options when looking at their freshman year of high school. Dr. Green, Assistant Principal at the Middle School, and the 8th grade teachers also toured the building. They mentioned their appreciation of the 10 PECHS Seniors that were the tour guides for the 8th graders. These Seniors were knowledgeable of the CTE trades and helped to answer questions and show the ins and outs of the CTE Building. Our CTE Teachers enjoyed showing off the passion that they have for their trades.

Elias Jones was a member of the class of 2013 when he died suddenly. Since then, his family has honored his memory by presenting a scholarship to recognize a graduating senior from PECHS who demonstrates leadership skills and good character. Any student who has been accepted into a college and plans to attend within six months of graduation is eligible to apply. The college may be a community college, a state college or university or a private, accredited college or university. This year the scholarship grant will be for two thousand five hundred dollars. This scholarship is only available to Prince Edward High School seniors. The application packet is available in the counseling office. Applications are due by April 16.
This is just one of many scholarship opportunities available. Check the high school announcement page daily to stay connected. http://www.hs.pecps.k12.va.us/news/announcements
